bibl.title: Letter from M.A. Barber to Henry Rose Carter, November 5, 1924

div1.p: Barber discusses his experiments and provides his observations on the longevity, breeding, and feeding habits of the Anopheles mosquito.

div1.head: Letter from M.A. Barber to Henry Rose Carter, November 5, 1924
div1.opener:
Malaria
Barber-
OFFICE OF
MEDICAL OFFICER IN CHARGE
TREASURY DEPARTMENT
UNITED STATES
PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE
Crowley, La. Nov. 5, 1924.
My dear Dr. Carter:
div1.p:
Your letter Oct. 29 received this morning, and, as always,
I was much pleased to hear from you.

As regards the question of longevity of confined Anopheles.
In cages one gets not only protection from enemies but also a high degree
of moisture. Again those of us who have had a large experience in infection
experiments find that it is usually only the strong which survive. Often
whole batches will dies early in spite of our care. Dr. King, who
visited us here recently, told us that in his experience Anopheles usually
died when put into a large screened cage, but survived much better in
test tubes-one to a tube. In cages too, we usually see that our Anopheles
are well fed, although many will survive a long time if given only the
initial blood feed. Last summer we had a good chance to repeat
the experiment of longevity of Anopheles (mostly quads) when shut in a room.
Water was provided in the room and sacking hung so that part of it
kept moist. In spite of this additional moisture, in four days there were only
3 survivors (females) out of an original number of nearly 500 both sexes.

As you suggest, it would seem that Anopheles do not often survive
long in ships at sea. I do not think that the danger of the wider distribution
of harmful species though
steamers is eliminated by the short life of mosquitoes
in rooms, etc., but it does not seem to be great in case of the longer distances.
Your have doubtless noticed the work of Mac Gregor in Mauritious. He found
there, 1922, maculipalpis and funestus as well as costalis. Funestus
occured in large numbers and hd been overlooked in previous surveys.
Ross in commenting on this paper thinks it likely that funestus
is a recent importation. But does it not seem morel likely that
all these species have always been there and that the outbreak of malaria
1865 or thereaboutswas due to some other cause?

I have long been interested in the suggestion of Gill that humidity
may be an important factor in malaria epidemics through increasing
the average longevity of Anopheles and thus increasing the mathematical
chances of transmission. There seems to be an impression among observers
in this country that nearness to a wood promotes malaria independently
of the intensity of Anopheles. One reason why we chose this locality for work
was to test this question. Anopheles are so numerous everywhere here
on account of irrigated rice fields that the intensity factor
is to some extent eliminated. But it does not appear in our surveys
that nearness to the numerous wooded bayous here makes any material difference
in the malaria rate. There is so little malaria here anyhow, that our observations
are not very convincing, but in houses a few hundred feet from woods
there does not seem to be any more malaria than elsewhere.

I should be glad to get the photostats of the Russian data when you no
longer have any use for them. However, I have made summaries of them, and do not
need the original greatly. I suspect that when all the returns from
the Russian epidemic are in we will not find it necessary to attribute much
bof their malaria to barrel breeding or breeding on wet wood. The literature is
so full of half-baked observations of the habits of mosquitoes that I never
open a journal now without a small bag of salt handy. The more observations we
2.
make the less we seem to know. Here is an example of this thesias
This summer I have been trying to get something fundamental on the food of
Anopheline larvae. You know that stomach contents of larvae in nature gives
but little valid information, for they will ingest anything that comes along-
be it algae or arsenic. So I have begun with ova made free of bacteria and
other microorganisms through alcohol sterilization. Eggs thus treated are
transferred to sterileserum broth. Those tubes which remain clear three
days or so are transferred to media in sterilized flasks-tubes now have
numerous very lively larvae in them. To the sterilized flasks are added
pure cultures of certain organisms or sterile food-sometimes chlorophyl, sterile,
from the inside of plant tissue. Beuatiful growths on media plus
paramecium only, certain unicellular algae-pure culture also, and certain
bacteria. Also on combinations of these. On all of these, mosquitoes have
emerged beautifully. But when sterile blood cells, egg yolk and white,
and a great variety of things autoclaved of heated just enough to kill
them are added, there is very little development, no emergences thus far
and in only one case full grown larvae. It looked as if I had something
but here is the fly in the ointment, or rather a reason why the
fly did not appear in the ointment. If instead of a motile alga one uses
a living, non-motile form in pure culture as Scenedesmus growth is also
meager. Again in one culture I placed sterilized ground-up bodies of
Anopheles adults. Flask with very little water so that larvae had the food
placed under their noses, so to speak. Here I got full-grown larvae, and the
usual tests made of flask contents, microscopical examination, cultures in
various media show that my flask remained sterile of microorganisms.
So it seems that a large factor is the accessibility of the food, and it may
not be its digestibility at all. Dead bacteria and infusoria killed at low tem-
peratures fail to nourish, possibly because they sink to the bottom and
are not eaten by the young larvae.

But I have had so many larvae remain living but with little growth
of dead food placed convenient to them that it is possible that
accessibility is not the only factor. P ssibly in nature larvae commonly feed
on living things and only secondarily on dead materials because they
feed so largely at the surface. But the moral thus far is that an apparently
definite result may have to be reviewed in a different light.

So I have come to hesitate about publishing anything on the habits
of mosquitoes until I have made a good many observations.

I am sorry I can give you nothing first-hand on costalis. We did not
see this species in the P.I. or Malay States.

As regards breeding in barrels. One may see this not only when
other breeding places are few but also when the numbers of Anopheles are large.
In Stuttgart, 1920, it was often observed although other breeding places
were plentiful. I am inclined to agree with Van Dine that barrel breeding,
when it does occur, does not produce any large number of adults.

I hope I will get to see you in New Orleans this month. Immediately
after the meeting Mr. Komp and I expect to spend about two months on the
plantations of the United Fruit Company-invitation of Dr. Deeks. I spent a few
weeks there last winter. Main thing will be to get more information regarding
the epidemiology of malaria. It seems to me that one of our greatest needs
in this country is to know how much malaria there is in different places
and to correlate malaria intensity with numbers of Anopheles -or to see
what the one has to do with the other. Here in the rice country we have untold
A. quad. but comparatively little malaria. Wish I could talk it over with you.
We will probably be in Greenwood, Miss. next year.
div1.closer: With sincere personal regards, M.A. Barber.
